title: 107_s3011
content: The Act is known as the "Maximum Economic Growth for America Through Safety Improvements Act" or the "MEGA Safe Act." It includes a program for improving school crossing zones and other pedestrian and bicycle crossing zones. Section 104 of title 23, United States Code is amended to set aside $25,000,000 for a program to assist local governments in placing fluorescent yellow-green signs in school zone crossing and other pedestrian and bicycle highway crossing zones. The Secretary may use funds to place fluorescent yellow-green signs in school zone and pedestrian crossing areas on public roads. The Secretary must ensure that at least 0.5 percent of funds are allocated for projects in each State annually. The use of funds must comply with applicable State law and the Manual on Uniform Traffic Control Devices. The Federal government will cover 100 percent of the project costs funded under this subsection. The Rural Local Roads Safety Pilot Program is established under Section 3. The term "eligible activity" in the Rural Local Roads Safety Pilot Program refers to projects or activities carried out on rural minor collector or rural local roads that provide a safety benefit. It includes projects described in section 133(d)(1) of title 23, United States Code. The Rural Local Roads Safety Pilot Program includes eligible activities such as road surfacing, improvement of local bridges, road reconstruction, signage installation, maintenance for safety, and acquisition of materials for these projects. The Secretary will establish a rural local roads safety pilot program for eligible activities, with funds allocated to State transportation departments based on a specific ratio. Terms used in the program have meanings from title 23, United States Code. Each State receives funds based on a ratio under section 105 of title 23, United States Code. States must allocate funds to counties based on the ratio of rural road miles within each county to the total rural road miles in the State. The State transportation department may use an alternative formula for allocating funds received under subsection (c) for rural local roads or rural minor collector roads, as long as it complies with State law and ensures funds are allocated within the State according to a program. The State transportation department may retain up to 10 percent of allocated funds for administrative costs. Counties or the State may select eligible activities for fund utilization. The State transportation department can retain up to 10 percent of allocated funds for administrative costs. Eligible activities in a State must be chosen according to the State alternative. Funds for this section can be obligated similarly to those apportioned under title 23. The Federal share of eligible activity costs is 100 percent. A report must be submitted by the Secretary by January 1, 2009, after allowing input from States, local governments, and other stakeholders. The House of Representatives infrastructure report outlines progress and recommendations for a program, with authorization of $200,000,000 annually from 2004 to 2009 from the Highway Trust Fund. SEC. 4. AGGRESSIVE DRIVING PREVENTION. Chapter 1 of title 23, United States Code, is amended to designate the left lane of each highway on the Interstate System as a national passing lane. The Secretary will provide funding to states for education on using these lanes for passing only. Funding of $51,000,000 is authorized annually from the Highway Trust Fund for this purpose. The section authorizes $51,000,000 annually from the Highway Trust Fund for education on using the left lane of highways as a national passing lane. SEC. 5. SAFE DRIVING INVOLVING PASSENGER VEHICLES AND TRUCKS. The amendments for aggressive driving prevention take effect on October 1, 2003. The Secretary of Transportation will provide a $1,000,000 grant to conduct a study on educating drivers about safe driving around tractor-trailers and passenger vehicles. The American Trucking Associations and American Automobile Association must submit reports to Congress to receive the grant. The American Trucking Associations and American Automobile Association must submit an interim report by October 1, 2003, and a final report by October 1, 2004, to Congress detailing the progress and results of the study on educating drivers about safe driving around tractor-trailers and passenger vehicles. SEC. 6. WORKZONE SAFETY. The Secretary of Transportation will require a trained person to oversee traffic control plans on highway projects using Federal funds. SEC. 7. CONFORMING AMENDMENTS. SEC. 7. CONFORMING AMENDMENTS. Repeals Section 351 of the Department of Transportation and Related Agencies Appropriations Act, 2001, and amends Sections 154(c)(2) and 164(b)(2) of title 23, United States Code, regarding fiscal years.
